body:
Thanks for letting us know about this issue.

This isn't a general Angular 2 file. The `es6-shim.js` is just a big glob of concatenated files that allow you run ES6 code in a current browser. It's just to get people up and running for the quickstart on the angular.io site.

All of this will change when TypeScript 1.5 releases with meta-data annotation support. Which I hope is soon!

Hey thanks for the PR!

I don't think we can add this though. I believe that adding the index.html, writing the component, and setting up the System paths are a core part of the learning process.

If we added this change, we would have to change the title to the 2 minute quickstart!  :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
Can you provide your code or some screenshots?

Yes. This is a manual process right now. We'll be working towards making this automatic in the future.

If you want to update yourself you can just run the default gulp task included in the repo.

Hello!

Annotations should not have trailing semicolons. This is the natural syntax of the language.  I don't feel that a callout is necessary either. None of the provided code has a trailing semicolon around annotations. If you use the code samples verbatim they will work as intended.

Hello!

Thanks for the PR! We have a process we run through before updating the quickstart repo. I'm sure your code is exactly the same but I need to run the same reproducible process on my end.

This is because angular 2 depends on rx, but it's missing from our quickstart.

_Workaround_: Add it to your package.json and System.path, as patternMiner has here
https://github.com/patternMiner/pattern_search/blob/master/package.json
https://github.com/patternMiner/pattern_search/blob/master/index.html

Note that quickstart was made for the steps outlined on http://angular.io . Running `gulp` is not one of those steps. It is required only to move the quickstart to a newer angular2 version.

This second commit fixes #13 provided that `System.path` is changed to:

``` javascript
      System.paths = {
        'angular2/*':'/quickstart/angular2/*.js', // Angular
        'rtts_assert/*': '/quickstart/rtts_assert/*.js', // Runtime assertions
        'services/*': 'services/*.js',
        'rx/*': '/quickstart/node_modules/rx/*.js',
        'app': 'editor.js' // The my-app component
      };
```

on https://angular.io/docs/js/latest/quickstart.html

This is still broken. For me it was enough to add

```
'rx/*': '/node_modules/angular2/node_modules/rx/*.js',
```

to the System.paths, as it was already in my node_modules.

I experienced the same error.  The command seems to be doing what it needs to, so I instructed gulp_shell to ignore the error:

```
// strip off the sourceMaps.
gulp.task('build:strip_maps', shell.task(["sh strip_maps.sh"], {ignoreErrors:true}));
```

...that seemed to result in an empty `dist/es6-shim.js` file - not much use.

What did work, was to add `|| true` at the end of `strip_maps.sh`:

```
sed -e '/^\/\/\# source/d' -i '' dist/es6-shim.js || true
```

We're going to be migrating off of this quickstart soon in lieu of a better solution.

Don't run any commands within this repo. The strip_maps file is not meant to ran in isolation either.

I'm sorry but I cannot duplicate. 

Works fine for me. What is your environment? What node version? What did you clone? 

**Are you updating or starting from scratch?** If updating, is it possible that you have multiple shim versions for the same shim library in your typings folder (due to update of the `typings` package)? If so, you could try deleting the `typings` folder and running `npm run typings install`. The easiest thing maybe to discard your current clone and clone again.

Please note that a clone of this repo is intended for one-time use. It's not designed to be updated and that usage will not be supported.

To be clear, the point of this repo is to make it easy for you to duplicate the end state of  the documented quick start.

From there you can venture in new directions the same way the documented samples do. For they all begin on this quick start foundation.

Because we update it for each release, you can be sure that it always works.

I agree that we shouldn't sell it as the ultimate anything. I like the mirroring statement.

But it is a viable starting place for experimental projects and I dont agree with pinning I to the samples or the ToH.

You need to load the corresponding file in a script tag, like the router or HTTP. Also keep in mind this is a quickstart project.

In the latest version, we run `tsc` FIRST and then concurrently `tsc:w` and `lite`.

Yes, that runs `twice` each time you start. But it avoids the race condition in which the server starts before the first tsc finishes.

And if the first `tsc` fails, it aborts the entire task so the `concurrently ...` never happens. At least such has been my experience.
Sorry, dude.  I went a different direction with this. I am updating the README to make the limitations more clear.
Added coincidentally as part of c18870fb02801c395bdba53e9d18cc7877c14fed

The `tslint.config` file is something I have been trying to tune. It's pretty close at this point. I relaxed some rules that were always getting in the way. Others I added to make sure we follow our guidelines.

Thanks Ward,

No need to reply, but here is the way I think about this:

Yeah I hear 'ya about the race condition, but it still seems better that the server starts up with errors, rather than not starting at all - the compiler will catch up after all. The big issue is that it's not super obvious that it's a script compilation error that's holding up the server from running. 

What I would expect here is that the server _always_ starts. if there is an error that error will show up either on the page (with console errors) or on the command line, but at that point I can fix and then see the change immediately. This is especially frustrating if you've had it work before assuming the server would always be there, and then fail another time because an error was introduced 'offline'. Then it's easy to miss the compile error and wonder why no server is loading :-)

Thanks. I can make this change myself, now that I know and hopefully there will be options on the TS compiler that let you control the result code returned.

@filipesilva `ng build -prod` doesn't embedded all of the application's .js files in the final `main.js` file. 
But the above gulp tasks, create a single `js/bundle.js` file which contains all of the angular2 related files + application's files (all of them).

benefits :
- single file deployment.
- less round trips to the server
- you can invalidate the cache of the browsers very easily, just by adding a simple query string at the end of the path (?v=1.x). But with deploying all of the .js files, cache invalidation won't happen easily.

Hello,  after a quick search, this issue may due to I used the `sudo`, here are 2 kind of solutions
1.Run npm install with the --unsafe-perm flag:

``` bash
[sudo] npm install --unsafe-perm
```

2.Add the unsafe-perm flag to your `package.json`:

``` javascript
"config": {
    "unsafe-perm":true
}
```

But use `unsafe-perm` may have risk one guy mentioned.

> It presupposes the existence of a `package.json` with systemjs config

No, it makes SystemJS respect `"main"` setting in package.json files and most npm packages have this one (including `@angular/*`). You still can (and should) add `packages:{…}` to your systemjs.config.js for packages which don't have `"main"` in their package.json but definitely it makes life easier for _most_ of the packages.

## Prerequisites

Node.js and npm are essential to Angular 2 development. 
- We certify specific version — node `v5.x.x` and npm `3.x.x` — for this QuickStart. 
  Both older and newer versions produce errors.
- We recommend [nvm](https://github.com/creationix/nvm) for managing multiple versions of node and npm.

You need to add:

```
'angular2-in-memory-web-api': { main: 'index.js', defaultExtension: 'js' },
```

That is an interesting opinion expressed by the writer there, but I don't agree with their interpretation of that section of the TypeScript documentation. In fact, the setting appears to work quite well for its intended purpose, and of course the ability to produce a SystemJS bundle is also noted in the TypeScript documentation.  It will take ordinary typescript modules in files as input, and it can produce either a separate file for each module of output, or it can produce a bundle. This demonstrably works, shown in my tiny commit above, and is in use on substantial projects "in the wild".  The sentence references, at the end of the following page, is incorrect.

https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-Handbook/blob/master/pages/Namespaces%20and%20Modules.md

Of course this is all irrelevant to the actual issue here, which is whether there is merit in using this setting in the quickstart, and I think the answer to that is universally no.

Closing because this seems "solved".

Why remove angular2-in-memory-web-api?

The #1 reason - it breaks the build. It could be fixed after 0.0.13 will be published but there is a question: is this really something we need to be a part of _quickstart_? At least it's not mentioned [here](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/quickstart.html) (except the listing of `package.json`)

This repo serves as a starting point for all tutorials at angular.io and some of them uses the in memory web api (the tutorial for example) so we simply assume that the in memory api is already there.

I was under the impression that the Quickstart was for developing Angular 2 projects in Visual Studio 2015. If I am mistaken, please advise.

That being said, as of Step 3 in the QuickStart documentation, it is suggested to open a new ASP.NET project in Visual Studio. While suggested workflow works for ASP.NET 4.x projects, things have changed in ASP.NET 5 - better known as ASP.NET Core - projects. The impression left wasn't one with a focus on ASP.NET development, but more of a workflow with said projects.

As of recent updates to Visual Studio 2015 and the introduction of ASP.NET Core, the project structure has changed slightly, including explicitly having `wwwroot` in the root of the project - where static files are intended to reside and be viewed in the browser. As a result, the steps provided in the QuickStart for Visual Studio 2015 don't necessarily apply.

The assumption was that the QuickStart was intended to help get things up and running quickly in Visual Studio. Doing a full deploy - using Webpack or otherwise - seems like overkill at that point. However, as it stands, some additional consideration for the latest project workflow in Visual Studio would be helpful.

Made obsolete by https://github.com/angular/quickstart/pull/158

Concurrently has the `--kill-all` functionality that was previously broken on windows/mac, but now is fixed. It is used for the e2e and unit tests on travis.

Thanks, @kahlil, but we're going to stick with `concurrently`.

Here's why (per one of our authors):

## 

We need functionality from `concurrently`. It's not just a matter or looking better.

It's the `--kill-others --success first` flags we added in PR #158 
`--kill-others` will terminate the other processes when the first finishes
`--success first` will give the status code of the first process to finish

These two together allow `concurrently \"http-server -s\" \"protractor protractor.config.js\" --kill-others --success first"` which means "run http-server and protractor at the same time, and once protractor is done kill off http-server"

Another way to fix it is to change `target` to `es6` in your `tsconfig.json`:

```
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "target": "es6",
        "module": "commonjs",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "removeComments": false,
        "noImplicitAny": false
    }
}
```

To app.component.ts, I added at the top:

```
import { FORM_DIRECTIVES } from '@angular/forms'; 
```

and within `@Component({`, I added

```
   , directives: [FORM_DIRECTIVES]
```

Thanks for the PR.

Unfortunately I cannot merge it.

This quickstart is not meant to be used an as starter point to "any project" (can be used for that, but is not the main goal).

This quickstart is a mirror of the "Quickstart" page at [angular.io](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/quickstart.html).

If you go there, you will see that the `FormsModule` is never mentioned, so if I merge this in here, this repo and that tutorial won't be in sync anymore.

Since this "Quickstart" is meant to be a starting point for the documentation, we left it without the Forms because we explain what the FormsModule is at the forms tutorial and is there where we add it.

Now, if you want a good starting point, you could start testing the webpack branch of the CLI.

Cheers.

- Many symbol names collide, making it difficult to understand scope and usage.

### Details

Trying to configure karma and systemjs has been very difficult.
I would appreciate any references you could provide me.

**karma**
I can't say I understand how karma works yet, and there doesn't seem to be much of a tutorial.
All I've found is: http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/intro/how-it-works.html,
which is surprisingly terse. It refers to a masters thesis, which I haven't read yet, but I'm looking for something in between, and which is specific to karma.

The karma configuration seems to be much more complex than what is described in http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/config/configuration-file.html and http://karma-runner.github.io/1.0/config/files.html.

**systemjs**
I feel I have a better understanding of the system.js loader.
I found the documentation on the https://github.com/systemjs/systemjs to be easier to understand, but it is still a complex component that will take me some fair time and work to understand.

**karma and system.js together with angular**
In particular, I'd like to understand the details of how browser URLs are sent to the karma server, and how they are resolved. I don't understand what resolution is performed in the browser, and what is performed by the karma server, which paths are relative, and which are from the root.  The documentation seems to assume that the reader already understands these things. I also don't understand what the special prefix **/base/** refers, and I can't find documentation that discusses this.

Another point of confusion is that the same symbol names are used for many things. 
I think that using a separate symbols for each concept would help greatly.
In particular, **app** has many uses, and I believe many people in the community assume that it's use is required, for example this [question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38886456/how-do-i-configure-the-code-directories-in-karma-for-angular2). I'm used to web-apps not knowing the file system structure of the server, but it seems like many portions of the URLs are expected to match.

**changing the project directory structure**
I have several components in one project.
You can find my first attempt in the [browser-angular2 component of people-service](https://github.com/psnider/people-service/tree/master/components/browser-angular2).
This was basically working, but broke when zone.js upgraded, see [issue](https://github.com/angular/quickstart/issues/186).
Then as I started to work through this, the tutorial was updated to RC5, so I'm redoing the work to incorporate it.

Found another solution, that I like better:

Instead of the changing app/app.component.spec.ts as above, modify **app/app.component.ts**:

add this import at the top:

```
import { HeroDetailComponent } from './hero-detail.component';
```

then add this **directives** field to the **@Component decorator**:

```
  directives: [HeroDetailComponent]
```
Please update the tutorial with whichever change is preferable.

+1 to this. There seems to be no "best-practice" to deploy angular 2 apps.

My guess is that this recommendation is more obvious within the context of a larger application and development environment. Running the app and tests simultaneously could cause one or more of the processes to run inefficiently and take longer, especially within an org with many unit and **especially e2e tests**. If the application runs slowly because you've got a lot of memory allocated to your tests, it could falsely convey that the application itself has a performance issue.

Just my two cents, I could be way off.

**\- Edited to reflect emphasis on e2e test performance impacts.**
@saadaouad Thank you very much, Now works fine,

Maybe you're right. But actually, I don't think so. Most likely you have plenty of other programs running while developing. Browser, IDE, email client, feedreader, ... maybe even some backend services you are also developing. lite-server is just one more. That shouldn't be much of a problem. In other words: If that's the problem, then lite-server would be a performance nightmare anyway (which I don't believe).

While it is perfectly fine (and encouraged) to run the unit tests in watch mode while coding your app, running the e2e tests as well is overall a bad idea. The answer lies in what you said:

> When developing my application I'd like to have **immediate feedback**.

Unit tests are usually fast because they test the classes etc in isolation. So mostly it's just some bits of code running, albeit the tests might number in the hundreds.

E2E tests, however, are a different beast all together. They work by firing up the browser, interfacing with it via protractor, and running a bunch of interactions as if you were doing them yourself. Meaning it's clicking on buttons, sending keys to input fields, etc on chrome. This is way more computationally intensive, and overall slow, than unit tests.

So while 500 unit tests might take ten seconds, it's not that uncommon to have 100 e2e tests take 20 minutes.

Essentially this means that e2e tests can never give you the immediate feedback you want and need, while unit tests kinda can.

Yes, this issue was created with SystemJS and Karma.

I figured it out, it's actually is a silly bug. The error reported is a socket error, Karma tries to run on the defined port and on failure we have something like:

`Chrome 52.0.2743 (Linux 0.0.0): Executed 0 of 3 SUCCESS (0 secs / 0 secs)`
`Missing error handler on socket.`

This can be easily reproduced if you start `npm run test`, stop/pause the process and attempts to run it again.

I saw somewhere else a Karma config that auto increments the port until it picks a free port.

I guess we could auto discover the port, but if the problem is that the port isn't available... then the solution is to make that port available. Adding port auto-discovery is a non-essential optimization imho, and this is a quickstart.

Unless there's a strong argument otherwise, I think this issue is closed.

@jacksoncharles you should either use `typings`, `dt` OR `@types/`. Using more than one of these at the same time will (and should) give you duplication errors.

Heya @psnider, we have a revised and very complete Testing guide at https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/testing.html#!#setup-files. It doesn't answer all of difficulties, but I think it answers most of them.
Thanks @filipesilva. I was hoping for a more idiot friendly answer aka: how do I swap to use @types? :-)

Assuming you're using `typings` this is what you should do:
- delete `typings` folder (where all the installed typings are), `typings.json`
- in `package.json` delete `"postinstall": "typings install",` and `"typings": "typings",`
- do `npm install @types/{core-js,jasmine,node,protractor,selenium-webdriver} typescript@latest --save-dev`
- configure your editor to use the local Typescript 2.0 (for VSCode follow https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions)

Those should be all steps. https://github.com/angular/quickstart/pull/157 should update the quickstart to `@types/` sometime in the next months.

# Don't change your target to ES6!!

@bedrin I don't mean this to be condescending or rude, but do you understand what changing your target to ES6 means? Am I the only person who thinks that is a bad solution? Having a target of ES6 means that the Typescript compiler is going to compile your Typescript code not to ECMAScript 5, but ECMAScript 6. ES6 is _quite far from being fully supported_. [See the Kangax ES6 compatibility tables](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/) if you  are uncertain of this. If your project is going live on the internet, and it likely is, you _probably_ want users with the non-latest browsers (IE11, 10, 9, many phone browsers) to still be able to use your product. Safari doesn't even support a single part of the fat arrow function syntax, for instance.

Why does it fix the error, then? The reason setting your target to ES6 works is because ES6 natively supports promises.

### For anyone else who is coming here and thinks that targeting ES6 is a mistake here's the deal:

As of the time of this writing we should be using Typescript 2.0+. There's really no good reason not to with angular in final release status. The NG2 quickstart now provides TS2.0+ as a default starter version in their package.json, and the Typescript team is focused on it 

There are a few typings definitions needed for Angular. The new recommendation according to TS is to use NPM to manage your Typings, and we can finally ditch this huge confusing headache that was Typings definitions/config files. Angular 2 uses core-js, so we need to use:

`npm install --save-dev @types/core-js`

Many of your other `cannot find name [some-symbol]` errors will/should now be solved by simply installing your typings via NPM to your package.json. I don't even have a typings.config file anymore.

Sounds too good to be true, doesn't it? Well it's not. It's the future, and we're already in it. Sweet.

[Read more here](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/consumption.html) on the TS 2.0 way to consume typings.

P.S. I do still think that _finding_ typings definitions is the biggest pain, since there is usually no good correlation between a "missing name" and what typings definition actually provides support for that, but that's a different (and very frustrating) topic.

Heya @thomasmerieux, we don't add all polyfills but we have a documentation page listing the necessary one for each browser: https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/browser-support.html

The "fix" is for the problem of running e2e tests in Travis. _They ran fine locally before this commit_.

See https://github.com/angular/webdriver-manager/issues/121 which describes how Travis is stuck on an old version of Chrome and ONLY by pinning to "old" versions of protractor and webdriver can we make tests pass in Travis.

The sad consequence (for now) is that consumers of this QuickStart get an old, arguably "wrong" version of protractor and webdriver.  We don't control Travis. We will fix as soon as possible.

  "tsc": "./node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc",
  "tsc:w": "./node_modules/typescript/bin/tsc -w"
}
```

This project does not use the `typings` package anymore, so if you are experiencing a typings related problem the answer is not to do `npm install typings`. As @layton-glympse said, it is also not to target ES6 (for the reasons listed).

If you're experiencing `Cannot find name 'Promise'.`, it's most likely because you changed something from the base setup or did not finish installing the node packages. Do this:
- freshly clone this repository
- run `npm install` and make sure it finishes successfully
- copy the `app` folder of your existing project into this new project

  'node_modules/systemjs/dist/system.src.js',
  'node_modules/systemjs/dist/system-polyfills.js',
```

Adding this:

Something else is wrong with your setup. You definitely do not ... and should not ... make the changes you've described.

The node type information should be coming from the npm installation of `node.d.ts` which you should see in `node_modules/@types/node` ... and obviously you do have that ^^^

The `exclude` option is present because the see takes pains to exclude compilation any AoT-specific files.

You never want the TS compiler to compile anything in `node_modules`.
The TS compiler normally excludes `node_modules` by default. But once you start excluding _anything_ you have to exclude everything explicitly, including  `node_modules`. Not doing so is why "_compilation take forever_".

Excluding AoT files isn't necessary in a seed and I'm going to remove it which means I'll be removing the _entire `exclude` clause_. 

I'm compiling just fine. But I'll be that won't work for you because something else is weird in your world.

I'm guessing you some how are compiling with an old version of TypeScript or npm or something in your environment that I can't see.

I can assure you that **this seed works when installed cleanly**. There is no issue on our end in the absence of information from you about your environment. So I'm closing this. You'll just have to keep looking for what's different in your world. Sorry.

Its a way of extending the SystemJS configuration with other mappings if your tests require them (e.g., "barrels"). You could modify `systemjs.config.js` directly but we'd rather you didn't. So it looks for this extra file in case you have extra configuration.

You can ignore it until you need it. Even deleting it won't hurt ... you'll just get console messages about it.

The issue is you need to provide right directory structure to load all files by karma 
 if you look at angular-quickstart repo -> karma.config.js. A simple missing '/' would change the file pattern load.

var appBase    = 'dist/src/'; 
{ pattern: appBase + '**/*.js', included: false, watched: true },

Heya, it looks like you accidentally changed part of your npm script in `package.json`.

Make sure it looks like this:
```
"start": "tsc && concurrently \"tsc -w\" \"lite-server\" ",
```
Oh and there's no need to have any package globally installed. Whatever is on `package.json` scripts always has the local node_modules added to path!

I agree that this is a useful feature, and you've implemented it in a very succinct way. It is outside the scope of the quickstart though, and that's the only reason for which I will close the PR and not accept it.

A fix seems to already be in master and I suppose it will be out in the next release.

Per @filipesilva, rather than modify package.json, use a specific version of selenium-webdriver:

npm install @types/selenium-webdriver@2.53.33

Can confirm that on Windows the only needed change is changing this line `package.json` from
```
    "@types/selenium-webdriver": "^2.53.33"
```
to
```
    "@types/selenium-webdriver": "2.53.33"
```
Then an `npm install` and `npm start` should work like normal.

You need to configure the `TestBed` in the spec to also include that new component. See more in https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/guide/testing.html#!#testbed
I configured the `TestBed` to declare the component but the error from the new build (see the updated link in the description) is the same.

I mean something different though: you have to add the *new* component to the testbed for `app.component.spec.ts` since now it needs to know about it.

https://github.com/adelinor/quickstart/blob/master/app/app.component.spec.ts#L14
```
    TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      declarations: [ AppComponent, CustomComponent ]
    })
```

Hi i run to similar issue with you. 

While i'm not sure how to properly fix this issue but let me share my workaround.

First.
You may want to update your SHELL env var by pointing it to your git bash location.
` export SHELL="/c/Program Files/Git/bin/bash" `
change the path to where your git bash location.

If up until this point you succeed then no need to change anything else. If not (I'm not). Then there is a problem in path resolve process. when you look deep inside **spawn-default-shell/src/get-shell.js** Node Modules they are trying to compare our SHELL path with common shell regex.
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
that variable assume that all shell name must end with "sh" while in our case it turns out to be 
`C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash.exe`
which means ends with "sh.exe" then it trows an error. 

so the solution is change 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh$/;`
to 
`const DETECT_SH_REGEX = /sh/;`

Hope that helps, pardon me if i wrongly explain something.

For more detailed explanation or complete solution please look here:
[github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6](https://github.com/kimmobrunfeldt/spawn-default-shell/issues/6)

Note : Since this solution change one node modules which is outside our project, be sure to change this again once you "nuke" your node modules folder, OR submit a pull request to the cause of the problem.

Update : 10h37 20 Jan : doing another fresh git clone and running the `clone` , `install` , `e2e`  I am now no longer able to reproduce the error. I had observed the error for a few days on various other fresh checkouts, and for the life of me I can't see what's changed on my system if anything.  Closing this issue as I'm satisfied its most likely a really odd local machine issue. (from my noobie perspective)

**I think I've worked out the sequence of how I ended up with the symptoms described** 

- I was initially running the `npm run test` (unit test) and this was working ok. 
- I was following along  a play-by-play with @jonpapa and I believe I had done a few of steps before actually running e2e for the first time. 
- That test runs, and there's no visible error in the Chrome window that appears, however, if the title of the `Hello Angular` changes to something that the end to end spec does not expect the test fails, but the chrome window does not show anything similar to the error you see in a failed unit test
 - also, the output in the console window is quite long, and the text showing `1 failed spec(s)` had already scrolled off the window, and the only visible text is the `npm ERR! texts` with a very specific messaging encouraging the submission of an `angular-quickstart` bug report.
- I'm a noobie angular (and javascript) developer, and come from an ops-ish background, `fake, msbuild` etc, where I'm used to making sure the build outputs are as simple as possible, and can read like a story. 

**lesson learnt?**

- **Returning (1) to npm, plus we should be able to also return friendly error message**
- test on multiple machines?
- test with with colleague first, before submitting bug report
- protractor/jasmine (?) output should not show `npm ERR!` output from a test run, imho.
- ERR! should only ever be shown to indicate an unexpected script error, with the script itself, not with what the script is doing. If I see `ERR!` then should immediately be able to reason (with high confidence) that something in the build process is broken, not the latest code change. 
- It should be easy for a non programmer to read the build output and the error message should be self documenting. There is possibly scope for improvement in the build process that comes with the `quickstart` templates.
- the test failing, was actually valid, and was not a script error. The test executed successfully and returned a valid error result of (1). 
- possibly a discussion around how noisy should an 'npm' error be, and under what circumstances can we override the npm default error messages?
- If there is a way to return (1) to 'npm' as well as the appropriate error message to display, one for (verbose) and other for (standard) then that would be possibly be easy to configure?
- build code is mixed in tightly with `src` code in the quickstart. Possibly needs some simple separation.

Heya, I'm glad you got it sorted, and thanks for taking the time to write up your experience! 

I agree with you that npm errors are quite noisy. They also aren't very helpful by themselves to post back to repo maintainers. Those long error logs happen *specifically* because stuff is being ran as a [npm script](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/scripts). Basically it tacks on its own error message in addition to whatever the real command put out.

I haven't looked much into it but it would be nice to be able to remove that extra error text. I don't think there is a reasonable way to do it for new users though, that's the kind of thing that needs system configuration usually.

Here's an NPM issue on the topic: https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/6124

Seems you can do `npm run e2e --silent` (or `-s`).

There are some extra nonreadable characters, at least by RHEL7, within the file. 

`rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)` doesn't work either.

A `hexdump` of the file shows what's wrong:

```
(0)[11:06][tcrescenzi]~/web/frameworks-next/angular2-listbox/(master)λ hexdump non-essential-files.txt -C
00000000  2e 67 69 74 0d 0a 2e 67  69 74 69 67 6e 6f 72 65  |.git...gitignore|
00000010  0d 0a 2e 74 72 61 76 69  73 2e 79 6d 6c 0d 0a 2a  |...travis.yml..*|
00000020  2e 73 70 65 63 2a 2e 74  73 0d 0a 43 48 41 4e 47  |.spec*.ts..CHANG|
00000030  45 4c 4f 47 2e 6d 64 0d  0a 65 32 65 0d 0a 66 61  |ELOG.md..e2e..fa|
00000040  76 69 63 6f 6e 2e 69 63  6f 0d 0a 6b 61 72 6d 61  |vicon.ico..karma|
00000050  2e 63 6f 6e 66 2e 6a 73  0d 0a 6b 61 72 6d 61 2d  |.conf.js..karma-|
00000060  74 65 73 74 2d 73 68 69  6d 2e 6a 73 0d 0a 4c 49  |test-shim.js..LI|
00000070  43 45 4e 53 45 0d 0a 6e  6f 6e 2d 65 73 73 65 6e  |CENSE..non-essen|
00000080  74 69 61 6c 2d 66 69 6c  65 73 2e 74 78 74 0d 0a  |tial-files.txt..|
00000090  70 72 6f 74 72 61 63 74  6f 72 2e 63 6f 6e 66 69  |protractor.confi|
000000a0  67 2e 6a 73 0d 0a 52 45  41 44 4d 45 2e 6d 64 0d  |g.js..README.md.|
000000b0  0a                                                |.|
000000b1
```

The solution should be as simple as copying the file to your clipboard and then pasting it over the existing file. That worked for me.

Here's also a list without the offending characters you can paste into a file that will work with `xargs -a <file> rm -rf`

```
.git
.gitignore
.travis.yml
*.spec*.ts
CHANGELOG.md
e2e
favicon.ico
karma.conf.js
karma-test-shim.js
LICENSE
non-essential-files.txt
protractor.config.js
README.md
```

For those uncertain if it's working try `xargs -a <file> ls` and it'll show you what will be touched by the command.

I encountered pretty much everything @magnayn discovered in my first few days of using Angular, and wound up writing my own Webpack config.

It was a giant PITA that took:

-  3 different TypeScript loaders to find one that actually works (hint: `awesome-typescript-loader`)
-  Trawling through SO and issue boards to figure to figure out why I was getting cyclic dependency issues in the build (hint: `/angular(\\|\/)core(\\|\/)(esm(\\|\/)src|src)(\\|\/)linker/` - yeah, WTF)
-  Separate loaders for routine stuff like `templateUrl` to resolve _actual_ files, and not just throw cryptic console 404s
- Proper handling of HTML and CSS processing/minification (including postcss)
- Walking the tightrope that is `tsconfig.json` to appease both TypeScript and webpack and actually get it to _build something_ that works.
- Swapping out the 90% of starter kits that use Webpack 1, and miss out on tree-shaking of v2 and es6 modules
- Separate builders for universal Angular, so initial page dumps/SSR were possible
- Proper hot reloading -- not full refreshes like with browsersync

I'm a new ng user transitioning from React, so luckily I had some experience with wrestling webpack. For someone that's completely new to this, I have no idea how anyone has actually managed to deploy working ng2 code any further than their laptop. Kudos to anyone navigating this learning curve. I spent 5 mins on the official docs before submitting a PR for a pretty obvious error. It's a minefield, and seemingly an exercise that (for now out least) is left to the developer.

I'm still working on it, but I'm gonna finish my webpack config and post it as an alternative to the starter kits currently out there. Hopefully it helps save someone else 3 days of their life trying to get 'hello world' to compile.

The CLI is a great effort, but hiding the set-up behind magic is going to bite people in the ass before too long. Anyone coming from a 'magic' framework like Meteor will know exactly what I'm talking about.

And, I'm sure I speak for others @Foxandxss, I certainly appreciate all efforts to build something like this quickstart guide. My main peev as a new user is lack of 'official' consistency. A user is either faced with going it alone or trusting everything to the CLI. Neither is ideal.

A simple, solid webpack starter that works in browsers and generates first-page HTML - and is **kept up to date** - would be awesome.

I'll post my attempt at that here when it's finished, hopefully in the next couple of days.

good catch @trescenzi 

Although, to be clear, `-a` is not a valid xargs switch on OS X (at least Sierra). So even if the encoding is fixed, it'll still fail.

`rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)` works as-is on my Mac, even with the current format.

So I'd suggest either:

1. Fixing the file, and making `rm -rf $(cat non-essential-files.txt)` the official *nix blurb
2. Having separate instructions for OS X / other *nix flavours where `xargs -a` is valid

@leebenson I think `1.` makes the most sense. Sounds like you'd have to fix the file regardless and it's probably better to use a command that's valid on more *nix flavors(including OS X). 

Thanks for the quick response!
The webpack guide is getting better and better and it comes with fully development, test and production. Will bring AOT soon.

I also went into this issue today, and it finally got fixed by steps:

3. remove node_modules, and then do "npm install" again

Thanks. I am responsible for the changes but I forgot to update  it here.

Yes, the `indexOf` is not the best solution, but does the trick for now.

One more thing to try: Add this to the top of your ts file that needs Promises, Maps, etc:

`///<reference types="typescript/lib/lib.es6"/>`

If you use this instead of `///<reference path="../../node_modules/whatever"/>` then when you publish your code as a module, the reference still works!  This was very difficult and time consuming to figure out, and it appears to be magic.

When you start the app using `npm start`, the app is running in development mode by default and shows a console message that reads:

```
Angular 2 is running in the development mode. Call enableProdMode() to enable the production mode.
```

To run the app in production mode, you will need to add the following code to the [main.ts](https://github.com/angular/quickstart/blob/master/src/main.ts) file:

```typescript
import { enableProdMode } from '@angular2/core';

enableProdMode();
```

Once the code above is added to main.ts, `npm start` will run the app in production mode.

You can find more information about the `enableProdMode()` function here: [https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/core/index/enableProdMode-function.html](https://angular.io/docs/ts/latest/api/core/index/enableProdMode-function.html)

You'll find some discussion of how to start an angular 2 app in production mode here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/35721206/how-to-enable-production-mode-in-angular-2.

Apologies - the PR is intended for a forked version of this repo. I'm closing this PR.

Tour of heroes seems aimed at very new people. The repo is originally setup to compile from src and output compiled .js files back to src. People new to angular or new to the concept of having separate source .ts files and compiled .js files are likely to get confused. I thought it would be better to separate them.
You can always ignore the compiled .js in your editor so they are never seen.

There are ways to deal with it if you're an advanced user. But if the quickstart is aimed at people very new to angular and new to having separate compiled files, it would be nice if the compiled files weren't mixed in with the .ts files that have almost the same name and are superficially similar in content.
In any case, this repo will be deprecated really soon in favor of starting with the CLI.

may I know why this project is gonna be deprecated? I just started angular4 with this guide.

When we started writing the docs, we had SystemJS and we created all our documentation around that. We had a "quickstart" guide that was the entry point of the rest of the docs. That was the time when Angular CLI didnt exist.

Nowadays, we don't have that quickstart guide anymore and all the documentation is being adapted for the Angular CLI.

When that  happens, this repository will be deprecated. It served its purpose when we started, but today, Angular CLI is a better option in everything.

I had the same problem and red some suggestions here. So, I just generated a new temporary app with help of CLI and copied `.angular-cli.json` to the current project and it started to work!

- `ng new my-temporary-app`
- `cp my-temporary-app/.angular-cli.json ./`
- `ng serve --open`

Try to install:
```
"rxjs": "^6.0.0",
"rxjs-compat": "^6.0.0"
```
I had the same errors by migration from Angular 5.2.10 to 6.0.0 and It has solved the problem.
Here you'll find more information: https://github.com/ReactiveX/rxjs/blob/master/MIGRATION.md
Good Luck!)
Have the config at proper place and same as my other projects, yet giving this error. Am on ver 5.2.2 of angular

Hi, I have got the solution of this.
Just need to Set registry by using command **"npm config set registry http://registry.npmjs.org/"** in cmd

The tutorial is missing the import in the app.module.ts ; the changes should be added to the tutorial and the final code review section else this doesn't work.

The zip file download of the final code of tutorial 5 actually contains the changes but it isn't mentioned in the tutorial itself or the final code review tabs
In Angular 6, the file is renamed to `angular.json`, so you may need to run `npm install` to upgrade to Angular 6.

Its because it's searching for the angular-cli.json and it can't find it.
adding it back should work.

Another possible solution - restart your server
Stop it - Control + c
Start - npm start

Angular does not provide a way to replace the base class with a stub.  However, I have discovered that isn't really necessary.

We can create a Jasmine Spy for each of the methods in the base class, and verify they have been called.
That relieves us from testing all of the base class implementation when we just want to focus on the sub class.

`spyOn(component, methodInBase).and.callThrough()`

If there are injected dependencies to the sub class, or the super class, we do have the chance to replace these with Mocks using the `TestBed.configureTestingModule`.  If our sub class has its own constructor, the Mocks will be injected there and passed to the super class with the call to `super()` found in the subclass's constructor.  If our sub class doesn't have its own constructor, Angular will call the base class's constructor directly, with the injected Mock services we have set up.

Therefore, no special setup or config is needed to unit test this situation.  We just need to make sure to mock all the dependencies and they will be injected as expected, whether it's in the base or the sub.

For a large project with lots of classes that extend a base class, I have found that it is useful to create Mocks for each of my injected services.  For a service named `supplier.service.ts` beside that in the same folder I am now in the habit of making a `supplier.service.mock.ts` which has the same interface as the real service but has only Jasmine Spys for all of the method implementations.  Then, each time I need to test a component that extends a base, I just inject all the mocks that are needed by the base with the `TestBed.configureTestingModule`.  There is some boiler plate setup that appears in all of my tests, but at least the mock itself is just implemented in one place.

Finally, if you do decide to create `*.mock.ts` files for your services, they need to be registered somewhere to get your AOT build to work.  I created a separate module just for unit testing, where all of my mock services are registered.  (this isn't necessary in Angular 6 CLI-generated projects which have separate tsconfig files for testing.  in that case just add *.mock.ts to all the same places you see *.spec.ts configured in both tsconfig files).

One other thing I noticed, by carefully analyzing my base components that I use, is that for the most part these could be replaced with a base *service* instead.  There isn't really much benefit that my component gets from being composed with a base component.  All my base is really doing is calling things on services.  So, if I was going to write my app all over again, I would try to avoid component inheritance altogether, and if I think I need any common functionality I would place that into a service or interface instead.

Another important technique we have is TypeScript Interfaces.  If we notice a group of components is similar, we can create an Interface that describes the common functionality.  Then when we go to make a new component we easily conform to the contract by implementing the Interface.

Closing this issue, since this does not need attention from Angular team.

The bottom line is, Angular doesn't have a way to replace a base class with a mock.  But, we shouldn't need to.  Instead, we can use spies for methods on the base component, and/or we can use mocks for the dependencies of the sub class and the base class.

Hi to configure with visual studio you need to
1)download the quickstart
2)copy the quickstart into your vs project
3)restore packages by right clicking package.json in vs
4)point the cmd window to the path of /src dir and type npm start
5)also you need to make changes in the index.html for the relevant paths for npm modules
6)make changes in tsconfig.json 
{
  "compileOnSave": true,
  "compilerOptions": {
    "noStrictGenericChecks": true,
    "target": "es5",
    "module": "commonjs",
    "moduleResolution": "node",
    "sourceMap": true,
    "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
    "experimentalDecorators": true,
    "lib": [ "es2015", "dom" ],
    "noImplicitAny": true,
    "suppressImplicitAnyIndexErrors": true
  }
}

Happy Angular!
